title: 110_hr3678
content: The "Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007" changes the moratorium on internet taxes to extend until 2014. States that currently tax internet access are grandfathered in. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to define 'Internet access' for subsections (a) and (b) based on previous enactments. Exceptions apply until June 30, 2008, for taxes on Internet access related to telecommunications services. The Internet Tax Freedom Act Amendments Act of 2007 clarifies that taxes on telecommunications services related to Internet access are subject to exceptions until June 30, 2008. These exceptions apply if a state or political subdivision imposed such taxes in a way inconsistent with the Act before July 1, 2007, or if there is ongoing litigation seeking to enforce such taxes in a similar manner. No legislative construction can be inferred from this subsection or the amendments made by the Act for periods prior to June 30, 2008. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to define "Internet access" as a service that enables users to connect to the Internet and includes telecommunications purchased, used, or sold to provide the service. This definition also includes incidental services like home pages, email, and instant messaging. The definition of "Internet access" under the amended Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act includes services like home pages, email, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage capacity. It excludes voice, audio, or video programming, and other chargeable products or services that utilize Internet protocol. The amended Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act defines "Internet access" to include services like home pages, email, instant messaging, video clips, and personal electronic storage capacity. It excludes voice, audio, or video programming, and other chargeable products or services that utilize Internet protocol. The term "telecommunications" is also redefined to align with the Communications Act of 1934 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amended Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act redefines "Internet access" to include various online services but excludes certain products and services utilizing Internet protocol. Additionally, a specific exception is added to exclude State taxes on commercial activity, modified gross receipts, taxable margin, or gross income of businesses. The amended Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act sets criteria for state taxes on business activities, requiring them to meet specific conditions such as not being discriminatory and applying broadly to business activities. The amended Section 1105 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act allows states to modify taxes on business activities after November 1, 2007, as long as the changes do not significantly limit the range of taxed activities. No implications are to be drawn from this section regarding taxes before November 1, 2007. SEC. 5 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act is amended to include telecommunications and enable access to internet content. Section 1108 is removed. SEC. 6 addresses the sunset of grandfather provisions. SEC. 6 of the Internet Tax Freedom Act addresses the sunset of grandfather provisions, stating that certain states are exempt if they have repealed taxes on Internet access more than 24 months prior to the enactment of this provision. SEC. 7 specifies that the Act and its amendments will take effect on November 1, 2007.
